document.title: New York State Intermediate Science Currclum

FE71E3FE0FB8402695A591254D941C02.description:
Simple machines include a lever, a pulley, a wheel and axle, and an inclined plane.
A complex machine uses a combination of interacting simple machines, e.g., a bicycle.

816A4360A62C443482C22DB98C3DAE7D.description:
Machines can change the direction or amount of force, or the distance or speed of
force required to do work.

4504962CEA844C1E87B1D24FB1338225.description:
A machine can be made more efficient by reducing friction. Some common ways of
reducing friction include lubricating or waxing surfaces.

B6FAD65FD03B4C4CB9A15FFA7B5134A9.description: Friction is a force that opposes motion.

24E44744546C4B3BA132F9BDADA698CD.description: Machines transfer mechanical energy from one object to another.

6CA4DE33B26744CEBEB98C5BD50ABFAE.description: Electric currents and magnets can exert a force on each other.

F59CF0BFB408411AB39CBF8F4DA88A79.description:
Every object exerts gravitational force on every other object. Gravitational force
depends on how much mass the objects have and on how far apart they are. Gravity is
one of the forces acting on orbiting objects and projectiles.

352E4B1A21BC4138B651D54C5841B811.description:
Observe, describe, and compare effects of forces (gravity, electric current, and magnetism) on the
motion of objects.

884E129C2D7D426E9507DF1CD609BA81.description: For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.

3EB21D47D0CE4900B3C6507E5C876A5A.description:
Force is directly related to an object's mass and acceleration. The greater the force,
the greater the change in motion.

587BABBEC4F346248A527ADDDE6848F1.description:
An object's motion is the result of the combined effect of all forces acting on the
object. A moving object that is not subjected to a force will continue to move at a constant
speed in a straight line. An object at rest will remain at rest.

24414F3DDBA7473F8E411BD5FB010503.description: The motion of an object can be described by its position, direction of motion, and speed.

C237B3FDB4BF49019B0A85DC398722DE.description:
The motion of an object is always judged with respect to some other object or
point. The idea of absolute motion or rest is misleading.

9EFD534667CF4F8F88A680E46E73BC53.description: Describe different patterns of motion of objects.

3B809459E6CA4131BAED756DD763836B.description:
Introduction: Examples of objects in motion can be seen all around us. These motions result from an interaction of
energy and matter. This interaction creates forces (pushes and pulls) that produce predictable patterns of change.
Common forces would include gravity, magnetism, and electricity. Friction is a force that should always be considered
in a discussion of motion.
When the forces acting on an object are unbalanced, changes in that object's motion occur. The changes could
include a change in speed or a change in direction. When the forces are balanced, the motion of that object will
remain unchanged. Understanding the laws that govern motion allows us to predict these changes in motion.

C03F6CB4170B49D99C954037E73B3D01.description: Energy and matter interact through forces that result in changes in motion.

3FE91F30F0C24D06AAA78BE78555CC36.description:
Energy can change from one form to another, although in the process some energy
is always converted to heat. Some systems transform energy with less loss of heat than
others.

E9FE1D1B744A4BAB82FAF642F0B7626B.description:
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, but only changed from one form into
another.

FD69AA7C16B143E0804143AA4DC11384.description: Describe situations that support the principle of conservation of energy.

98943E1148AE430BA7A7D86F986FE2E4.description:
Without direct contact, a magnet attracts certain materials and either attracts or
repels other magnets. The attractive force of a magnet is greatest at its poles

DD59802B61EF4F0388114956B2B03CC5.description:
Without touching them, material that has been electrically charged attracts
uncharged material, and may either attract or repel other charged material

8F35360E3BE64365B630B2A1D7B47F62.description: Electrical circuits provide a means of transferring electrical energy

F9FB6AF837DE448A838107BF2B1B48E8.description:
Electrical energy can be produced from a variety of energy sources and can be
transformed into almost any other form of energy

D2BECAC51B1C4ECC8850FF8355230C64.description:
Vibrations in materials set up wave-like disturbances that spread away from the
source. Sound waves are an example. Vibrational waves move at different speeds in
different materials. Sound cannot travel in a vacuum.

6E63E555F5B0498DBD595B26D0411348.description:
Light passes through some materials, sometimes refracting in the process.
Materials absorb and reflect light, and may transmit light. To see an object, light from
that object, emitted by or reflected from it, must enter the eye.

5C71A4F4BBF54B65BC61DD00A2C6DD5C.description:
Different forms of electromagnetic energy have different wavelengths. Some examples
of electromagnetic energy are microwaves, infrared light, visible light, ultraviolet
light, X-rays, and gamma rays.

DF2F84CD51DE401280C548E6A4394925.description: Observe and describe the properties of sound, light, magnetism, and electricity.

9E76618F6C7643E1A34134CD583D03DC.description:
In chemical reactions, energy is transferred into or out of a system. Light, electricity,
or mechanical motion may be involved in such transfers in addition to heat.

A2AFA9A2D7854BC09E85578762A9A394.description: Observe and describe energy changes as related to chemical reactions

6D0DF2026FAC49A0A03ED8BFCE3D9ABA.description: Temperature affects the solubility of some substances in water.

ED6F12D128A54D0AAA1CA7E180179514.description:
Most substances expand when heated and contract when cooled. Water is an
exception, expanding when changing to ice.

8A181695FBEA498EBF4A797CB5EF1994.description:
During a phase change, heat energy is absorbed or released. Energy is absorbed
when a solid changes to a liquid and when a liquid changes to a gas. Energy is released
when a gas changes to a liquid and when a liquid changes to a solid.

5987B5330CA54BB688F6C133DA027780.description:
Heat can be transferred through matter by the collisions of atoms and/or molecules
(conduction) or through space (radiation). In a liquid or gas, currents will facilitate
the transfer of heat (convection).

2F7F83C184D84782AA1566898B1813B9.description:
Heat moves in predictable ways, flowing from warmer objects to cooler ones, until
both reach the same temperature.

CF11F0676D4A4EE2968A7B5BDC04F1C4.description: Observe and describe heating and cooling events.

AB556D2F32504A17BCBBB8BEC3F0E722.description:
Energy can be considered to be either kinetic energy, which is the energy of
motion, or potential energy, which depends on relative position.

2C0EC38EB7404C76807574C97BEBF1FB.description:
Different forms of energy include heat, light, electrical, mechanical, sound, nuclear,
and chemical. Energy is transformed in many ways.

F25E4D362D824B90ABEE3DBBDA02A97F.description:
Most activities in everyday life involve one form of energy being transformed into
another. For example, the chemical energy in gasoline is transformed into mechanical
energy in an automobile engine. Energy, in the form of heat, is almost always one of the
products of energy transformations.

A24C3C556D394D0F8A626711DFD564CE.description:
Fossil fuels contain stored solar energy and are considered nonrenewable resources.
They are a major source of energy in the United States. Solar energy, wind, moving water,
and biomass are some examples of renewable energy resources.

48B56951C26E4CB9AFD7DB1D60F0ED73.description:
The Sun is a major source of energy for Earth. Other sources of energy include
nuclear and geothermal energy.

BF47EC3E36F14763A5606C3A9A6296E2.description: Describe the sources and identify the transformations of energy observed in everyday life.

66C65A8EE6654F0DA1353772334C1258.description:
Introduction: An underlying principle of all energy use is the Law of Conservation of Energy. Simply stated, energy
cannot be created or destroyed.
Energy can be transformed, one form to another. These transformations produce heat energy. Heat is a calculated
value which includes the temperature of the material, the mass of the material, and the type of the material.
Temperature is a direct measurement of the average kinetic energy of the particles in a sample of material. It should
be noted that temperature is not a measurement of heat.

E4BAD7295A034FE88FC1AE1331FA8B25.description: Energy exists in many forms, and when these forms change energy is conserved.

14AAD105415A4F8E9E03E540F88D5936.description:
The periodic table is one useful model for classifying elements. The periodic table
can be used to predict properties of elements (metals, nonmetals, noble gases).

66B6763DBD2C4B9CB82753CEE79EE671.description:
There are more than 100 elements. Elements combine in a multitude of ways to
produce compounds that account for all living and nonliving substances. Few elements
are found in their pure form.

A5ED5A12664A45AFB4221C4BA294D233.description: The atoms of any one element are different from the atoms of other elements.

120246055C8D43DAA7FF8C7032B38E4E.description: Interactions among atoms and/or molecules result in chemical reactions

C825C65DD14F40A0AA37ECE83D32B3FE.description:
Atoms may join together in well-defined molecules or may be arranged in regular
geometric patterns.

7F1E130B519A411091AF930EEA6E2F93.description:
Atoms and molecules are perpetually in motion. The greater the temperature, the
greater the motion.

A22EF77832B647DC8E61438823CCE39D.description:
All matter is made up of atoms. Atoms are far too small to see with a light
microscope.

7609D67754B04AE198F608D18E1AE403.description: Develop mental models to explain common chemical reactions and changes in states of matter.

08AAFC81DFA44843BE34C39577E22FC8.description:
The Law of Conservation of Mass states that during an ordinary chemical reaction
matter cannot be created or destroyed. In chemical reactions, the total mass of the
reactants equals the total mass of the products.

1C8BF3EBD760486088AA889946F101B5.description:
Substances are often placed in categories if they react in similar ways. Examples
include metals, nonmetals, and noble gases.

F368D363B87242CA9D20381618101B42.description:
During a chemical change, substances react in characteristic ways to form new
substances with different physical and chemical properties. Examples of chemical
changes include burning of wood, cooking of an egg, rusting of iron, and souring of
milk.

A2A938385EC144C98C5F644EB3AA12F5.description:
Mixtures are physical combinations of materials and can be separated by physical
means.

844FAD4D35A44ACDB16199671B6E75C8.description:
During a physical change a substance keeps its chemical composition and properties.
Examples of physical changes include freezing, melting, condensation, boiling,
evaporation, tearing, and crushing.

EE90683B111441CDAAD70F0196CEDA0B.description: Distinguish between chemical and physical changes.

F7197EF2610C4443B746372383B90A71.description: Buoyancy is determined by comparative densities.

DCDF511F4E564AA381A3972462C23C14.description:
Density can be described as the amount of matter that is in a given amount of
space. If two objects have equal volume, but one has more mass, the one with more
mass is denser.

2520C3EA4ECB4D2BA6946AB4CB1172E9.description:
Characteristic properties can be used to identify different materials, and separate a
mixture of substances into its components. For example, iron can be removed from a
mixture by means of a magnet. An insoluble substance can be separated from a soluble
substance by such processes as filtration, settling, and evaporation.

A059E41EBE674476BC05796EC96A21D0.description: A solid has definite shape and volume. Particles resist a change in position.

4EF8A911A2BA4B81948672D74EE6D040.description: A liquid has definite volume, but takes the shape of a container

B933204CBE784D5EB9A94AD8A74DB0B5.description:
Gases have neither a determined shape nor a definite volume. Gases assume the
shape and volume of a closed container.

1A2D5F73E4E64BDD8F0F96487040D936.description:
The motion of particles helps to explain the phases (states) of matter as well as
changes from one phase to another. The phase in which matter exists depends on the
attractive forces among its particles.

B3081F4E6F80404A84154D97775E3500.description:
Solubility can be affected by the nature of the solute and solvent, temperature, and
pressure. The rate of solution can be affected by the size of the particles, stirring,
temperature, and the amount of solute already dissolved.

0CF0E0BC96064714921C86614C3BD813.description:
Substances have characteristic properties. Some of these properties include color,
odor, phase at room temperature, density, solubility, heat and electrical conductivity,
hardness, and boiling and freezing points.

BD507803AB8447C98883EB606282EEF5.description: Observe and describe properties of materials, such as density, conductivity, and solubility.

40C95E2E80944DE3B0B026A21272D6B0.description:
Objects in the universe are composed of matter. Matter is anything that takes up space and has mass. Matter is classified
as a substance or a mixture of substances. Knowledge of the structure of matter is essential to student's understanding
of the living and physical environments. Matter is composed of elements which are made of small particles
called atoms. All living and nonliving material is composed of these elements or combinations of these elements.

B8683C98FBD14C7DA452CD2327A047D4.description: Matter is made up of particles whose properties determine the observable characteristics of matter and its reactivity.

A651B742815645B9AE713442CB161CE3.description:
The Physical Setting: Students will understand and apply scientific concepts, principles, and theories pertaining to the physical
setting and living environment and recognize the historical development of ideas in science.

43873226CA294B2BBE98D4AD5D437BC3.description: determine the speed and acceleration of a moving object

B681517CDA4642AFB8D26FAA3077CDE4.description: determine the electrical conductivity of a material, using a simple circuit

160DC1D4990F4CB381A7B4F13BAE612E.description: using appropriate resources, separate the parts of a mixture

357D296A45754B69B9759833A21993DC.description: determine the identity of an unknown element, using physical and chemical properties

7E2FD1992CEA4DA8B2A4688997D32775.description: using the periodic table, identify an element as a metal, nonmetal, or noble gas

7D4E40333EEE4315B6B989C1FA4E2A1B.description: determine the volume of a regular- and an irregular-shaped solid, using water displacement

754E8C51BBAD4AAABC46736F0801088D.description: determine the density of liquids, and regular- and irregular-shaped solids

4BE7B760B24A445780D65BEE7CFF36C3.description: measure weather variables such as wind speed and direction, relative humidity, barometric pressure, etc.

6275CD022A444025B99B6093ABC648C7.description: predict the characteristics of an air mass based on the origin of the air mass

89E0D467029A4255825A50E9DC70AEC3.description: generate and interpret field maps including topographic and weather maps

B50E50C75DC547EA947303E821D78024.description: measure the angular elevation of an object, using appropriate instruments

4367D252051740DF83438F2237FDE738.description: use a magnetic compass to find cardinal directions

F1C857BC014143059550AC2BDFB83CD8.description: plot the location of recent earthquake and volcanic activity on a map and identify patterns of distribution

A52C2568D081445697D66CDB0A947F8F.description:
use a diagram of the rock cycle to determine geological processes that led to the formation of a specific rock
type

A7E42EB98FBC43E2843FD0570C87AC85.description: using identification tests and a flow chart, identify mineral samples

915E85B352354DF9A8A9A46A29DA63C1.description:
given the latitude and longitude of a location, indicate its position on a map and determine the latitude and
longitude of a given location on a map

E8264B01AB0446DC9BB5CCF92338E6E8.description: identify structure and function relationships in organisms

58A4190E2E2F40D49354BF8DB9E67E0A.description: identify pulse points and pulse rates

5FF4A6E7EC0648CD8D8072768919CA17.description: interpret and/or illustrate the energy flow in a food chain, energy pyramid, or food web

FC5A033B3DF343F18ABA338DFFCA4FD6.description: classify living things according to a student-generated scheme and an established scheme

0BFE31049CAD46DF9FD8FB81235DC6FC.description:
design and use a Punnett square or a pedigree chart to predict the probability of certain traits
6. classify

C962ABE189E44C6BB8BB26BF9005094D.description: determine the size of a microscopic object, using a compound microscope

F1160267E4C44439B7F55657B7FBCE1C.description: manipulate a compound microscope to view microscopic objects

59F0BFA06B2E44C08DC936F1F69583A9.description: develop and use a dichotomous key

770B2F54FB05436FBFA96283AD37A21B.description: classify objects according to an established scheme and a student-generated scheme

8B90C12F740249DFAA3CCC0D06F9E58B.description: recognize and analyze patterns and trends

F816A9A4FECC4C2E85E431B81A540D1A.description: use appropriate units for measured or calculated values

D7EA4AE7FA574F53A51DD991A3C39EFA.description: safely and accurately use the following measurement tools:

6044FEB77BFC419AB9BC614D95F49E8F.description: follow safety procedures in the classroom and laboratory

82F97D6447904A21BAAE33C64B8CCAFE.description:
Students participate in an extended, culminating mathematics, science, and technology
project. The project would require students to: ¥ Working Effectively: Contributing to the work of a brainstorming group, laboratory
partnership, cooperative learning group, or project team; planning procedures;
identify and managing responsibilities of team members; and staying on
task, whether working alone or as part of a group.
¥ Gathering and Processing Information: Accessing information from printed
media, electronic data bases, and community resources and using the information
to develop a definition of the problem and to research possible solutions.
¥ Generating and Analyzing Ideas: Developing ideas for proposed solutions,
investigating ideas, collecting data, and showing relationships and patterns in
the data. ¥ Common Themes: Observing examples of common unifying themes, applying
them to the problem, and using them to better understand the dimensions of the
problem.
¥ Realizing Ideas: Constructing components or models, arriving at a solution,
and evaluating the result.
¥ Presenting Results: Using a variety of media to present the solution and to
communicate the results.

5A23A06132D74E04A02F2362C1F50EC0.description:
Solving interdisciplinary problems involves a variety of skills and strategies, including
effective work habits; gathering and processing information; generating and analyzing
ideas; realizing ideas; making connections among the common themes of mathematics,
science, and technology; and presenting results.

CCA1B02D47AC462A8F7A348BA59293FF.description:
Describe and explain phenomena by designing and conducting investigations
involving systematic observations, accurate measurements, and the identification
and control of variables; by inquiring into relevant mathematical ideas; and by using
mathematical and technological tools and procedures to assist in the investigation.

B5A7FF108E4447ABB30C4CC554E43DB2.description:
Design solutions to real-world problems of general social interest related to home,
school, or community using scientific experimentation to inform the solution and
applying mathematical concepts and reasoning to assist in developing a solution.

C9C923D24217474F99AF0BB1722A570D.description:
Make informed consumer decisions by seeking answers to appropriate questions
about products, services, and systems; determining the cost/benefit and risk/benefit
tradeoffs; and applying this knowledge to a potential purchase.

2E9504FA9045496191481DC19B5A48C4.description:
Analyze science/technology/society problems and issues at the local level and
plan and carry out a remedial course of action.

E855790454F4417AB3C534807E15920E.description:
The knowledge and skills of mathematics, science, and technology are used together to
make informed decisions and solve problems, especially those relating to issues of science/
technology/society, consumer decision making, design, and inquiry into
phenomena.

81BE94DE1F884B919C91AB6399B0A5C2.description:
7—Interdisciplinary Problem Solving: Students will apply the knowledge and thinking skills of mathematics, science, and technology to address real-life
problems and make informed decisions.

D45F507334324AAFAC7246276DCBF6F3.description:
Use graphs of information for a decision-making problem to determine the optimum
solution.

C9A9041C34CA4DA88675C392427E29D0.description:
Determine the criteria and constraints and make trade-offs to determine the best
decision.

4AA1FA1B109144C9823D9AFA41DC71AD.description:
In order to arrive at the best solution that meets criteria within constraints, it is often necessary
to make trade-offs.

DAD1D392AA124922920A8CB8BDA75930.description:
Observe patterns of change in trends or cycles and make predictions on what
might happen in the future.

5F73172AAB8F4E5F88A6390A6A7424E3.description: Use simple linear equations to represent how a parameter changes with time.

771303B58C50414E85D4B89664E7C3F0.description:
Identifying patterns of change is necessary for making predictions about future
behavior and conditions.

1BF91351E82C4BCEBC471EDA7598FDB4.description:
Describe changes within equilibrium cycles in terms of frequency or cycle length
and determine the highest and lowest values and when they occur.

D9CC3D063C5D476A9D83F431ABC57F05.description:
Describe how feedback mechanisms are used in both designed and natural systems
to keep changes within desired limits.

4DDE84922FBC4084871BD36BCD06D4BA.description:
Equilibrium is a state of stability due either to a lack of change (static equilibrium) or a
balance between opposing forces (dynamic equilibrium).

F4754A67FC4E4E07AAB2975B5C73A0C7.description: Use powers of ten notation to represent very small and very large numbers.

4AD6F50F2D654818B87A7E05973D17DF.description:
Cite examples of how different aspects of natural and designed systems change at
different rates with changes in scale.

044D1C3886064EBB8AEDEC8E8901742A.description:
The grouping of magnitudes of size, time, frequency, and pressures or other units of
measurement into a series of relative order provides a useful way to deal with the
immense range and the changes in scale that affect the behavior and design of systems.

96F1524EF12041CA82EE96DAB029468E.description:
Demonstrate the effectiveness of different models to represent the same thing and
the same model to represent different things.

D606E3B047A641068FE158A131A35585.description:
Use models to study processes that cannot be studied directly (e.g., when the real
process is too slow, too fast, or too dangerous for direct observation).

D9AE8B607B5F406185ED66FB736F728D.description:
Select an appropriate model to begin the search for answers or solutions to a question
or problem.

07F25ADC352B42ACA2E3EF337A789D29.description:
Models are simplified representations of objects, structures, or systems used in analysis,
explanation, interpretation, or design.

0A953422F63C484FB82CF4125FFA263A.description:
Describe how the output from one part of a system (which can include material,
energy, or information) can become the input to other parts.

354F044C7538495BBF4C0739C39C1657.description: Describe the differences between open- and closed-loop systems.

6A626F04C5824E39904FBDC484BEA52C.description:
Describe the differences and similarities among engineering systems, natural systems,
and social systems.

8446DD50F6DF47D79B2C72CD73EE9CBC.description: Describe the differences between dynamic systems and organizational systems.

07C87A542FA84CA590EE8872EFE44ACD.description:
Through systems thinking, people can recognize the commonalities that exist among all
systems and how parts of a system interrelate and combine to perform specific
functions.

C55B985F77E3492B878ABD741F1456E0.description:
Interconnectedness: Common Themes:Students will understand the relationships and common themes that connect mathematics, science, and technology
and apply the themes to these and other areas of learning.

6AD0B4BD804E47DF90C29595F43A26EB.description:
Explain the impact of the use and abuse of electronically generated information on
individuals and families.

11C94D64AEC14A3885C7D5E052FADA8B.description:
Describe applications of information technology in mathematics, science, and
other technologies that address needs and solve problems in the community.

262FD915639A4D52924A6DFD0AE079BE.description:
Use graphical, statistical, and presentation software to present projects to fellow
classmates.

567FA3CE6B8543F89C23AAB9AEC0910F.description:
Information technology can have positive and negative impacts on society, depending
upon how it is used.

BE2083B77C4546ECB22B5631DD4403B9.description:
Understand why electronically stored personal information has greater potential
for misuse than records kept in conventional form.

EC98CE0AEC8D4F7085F7C6B6D10B77DC.description: Identify advantages and limitations of data-handling programs and graphics programs.

BC8AC2DA60004512B5EAE9B379128C44.description: identify and explain sources of error in a data collection

9057B1E0A6664A7B85B648A133C12032.description: critically analyze data to exclude erroneous information

CBE3E13FA6CB482A977ECF53BAC803E7.description:
Understand the need to question the accuracy of information displayed on a computer
because the results produced by a computer may be affected by incorrect
data entry.

8F03344AE28A456AAC743626295AA41B.description:
Knowledge of the impacts and limitations of information systems is essential to its effectiveness
and ethical use.

BCFA4CE610774740B5F80F25706AE005.description: Use simple modeling programs to make predictions

CF7225D5A0BF4098830F647C00F68AD4.description: use the collected data to communicate a scientific concept

F6FD3569D39E46F5BD9516DAD8249DA2.description: collect the data, using the appropriate, available tool

4E0E1A4221D74044BC1955820B81B781.description: Collect data from probes to measure events and phenomena.

811998ABB1A54177B40690EF22C40D2E.description:
Systematically obtain accurate and relevant information pertaining to a particular
topic from a range of sources, including local and national media, libraries, museums,
governmental agencies, industries, and individuals.

987023E3B2054CA39C4FDF8F305DBE05.description:
Use spreadsheets and database software to collect, process, display, and analyze
information. Students access needed information from electronic databases and
on-line telecommunication services.

DB8B8B8AC7BB440F8C1D3C8408EE9671.description:
Use a range of equipment and software to integrate several forms of information in
order to create good-quality audio, video, graphic, and text-based presentations.

455DA4A4E0DB4224A2ACDCB1AAA1F312.description:
Information technology is used to retrieve, process, and communicate information as a
tool to enhance learning.

96327854D9504C0097421D3FDDA0272E.description: Information Systems:Students will access, generate, process, and transfer information, using appropriate technologies.

49265E35B5EA4377B20C70D3498766D0.description:
In a group setting, test their solution against design specifications, present and
evaluate results, describe how the solution might have been modified for different or
better results, and discuss trade-offs that might have to be made.

D367DAD9B98047C796C11AFC0B54DD1A.description: construct a model of the product or process

E93F5DB2CDCE494EA834876C41D014C6.description: design and construct a model of the product or process

F58633BF25784C56B88527BF4AAAE209.description:
Develop plans, including drawings with measurements and details of construction,
and construct a model of the solution, exhibiting a degree of craftsmanship.

5E72BB2E3D1F4C60B1DBDDE5461711C1.description: evaluate alternatives based on the constraints of design

8D7EC679CFE748E2BBEB371495472934.description:
Consider constraints and generate several ideas for alternative solutions, using
group and individual ideation techniques (group discussion, brainstorming, forced
connections, role play); defer judgment until a number of ideas have been generated;
evaluate (critique) ideas; and explain why the chosen solution is optimal.

92A374A7A2C24EAEB3DAA51BBAC78888.description:
use all available information systems for a preliminary search that
addresses the need

1D0588D20F6B4247AB4FC64FAF5C6FB0.description:
Locate and utilize a range of printed, electronic, and human information resources
to obtain ideas.

4397EDABDFFB4D44B31E3BE64107A7BB.description:
identify a scientific or human need that is subject to a technological solution
which applies scientific principles

788C102F709444FA81642B0565D5F8B4.description:
Identify needs and opportunities for technical solutions from an investigation of
situations of general or social interest.

4A6781BAD4714B12B09FBC1D2D0E21E2.description:
Engineering design is an iterative process involving modeling and optimization (finding
the best solution within given constraints); this process is used to develop technological
solutions to problems within given constraints.

7F84BD1DC3934C4B8D9CFED90244CA78.description:
Modify their personal understanding of phenomena based on evaluation of their
hypothesis.

ABDE650B0D33437BA249DA30253DAD77.description: use and interpret graphs and data tables

302F273C5AD54FEAB72991A661CDC880.description: suggest improvements and recommendations for further studying

9A0B951201074E03ADB6C408E6FAB34B.description: make predictions based on experimental data

9FE9E7CC957B47DDACDD99D6C1794905.description:
form and defend a logical argument about cause-and-effect relationships
in an investigation

A0D448142AAA40C49CC689E00273A941.description:
formulate and defend explanations and conclusions as they relate to
scientific phenomena

4DFB343EE05A459DA37755EA76AE5094.description: evaluate the original hypothesis in light of the data

1EAFD2D12FB04CF7AF6B9E16768529C7.description: identify sources of error and the limitations of data collected

94888AF050CD4DF1BFD31D52CB134FE0.description: accurately describe the procedures used and the data gathered

0EA24E108C7F442E9AE54D9725E66D26.description:
Interpret the organized data to answer the research question or hypothesis and to
gain insight into the problem.

222D2BEF9CD0483890C1571C2A35249E.description: generate and use scales, create legends, and appropriately label axes

BA47FAB63CBC4D188A8C9557B484732B.description:
organize results, using appropriate graphs, diagrams, data tables, and
other models to show relationships

A16E79DE9E2648228C618795F388A951.description:
Design charts, tables, graphs, and other representations of observations in conventional
and creative ways to help them address their research question or hypothesis.

A001B6E8AE954C3C93386817C6A746D5.description:
The observations made while testing proposed explanations, when analyzed using conventional
and invented methods, provide new insights into phenomena.

6657ED113A39440E916999F0AB471626.description: Carry out their research proposals, recording observations and measurements(e.g., lab notes, audiotape, computer disk, videotape) to help assess the explanation.

62D628E2F75C4685B5E08748E3B1DB4F.description: choose appropriate sample size and number of trials

DAEC50EF3DF448BDBDFF171FA36F38F5.description:
identify independent variables (manipulated), dependent variables
(responding), and constants in a simple controlled experiment

4D436DB0D5F34CFD84188FE71203BA2A.description:
Develop, present, and defend formal research proposals for testing their own
explanations of common phenomena, including ways of obtaining needed observations
and ways of conducting simple controlled experiments.

941C51901811478EBB5BA8FB1BE5622D.description:
use appropriate tools and conventional techniques to solve problems
about the natural world, including: ¥ measuring ¥ observing ¥ describing
¥ classifying ¥ sequencing

37DEFFC202FD45589B42E88C50D07E1A.description: design and conduct an experiment to test a hypothesis

9A73BEFCC0D34581B745D9608FB18D66.description: conduct an experiment designed by others

14124115258F4A3591FA3F678D19DDF7.description:
Use conventional techniques and those of their own design to make further observations
and refine their explanations, guided by a need for more information.

D68FBBB58D39414697FD26CE2C43D4C9.description:
Beyond the use of reasoning and consensus, scientific inquiry involves the testing of proposed
explanations involving the use of conventional techniques and procedures and usually
requiring considerable ingenuity.

696109E595184732914972CFA4DA21E5.description: Seek to clarify , to assess critically, and to reconcile with their own thinking the ideas presented by others, including peers, teachers, authors, and scientists.

6F6468AF0B9F4EAF95D0B87F3805938A.description: represent, present, and defend their proposed explanations of everyday observations so that they can be understood and assessed by others
